body.p:
Your favor 25st ulto came duly to
hand this day and I had become somewhat fearful that my
letter had miscarried in consequence of not hearing from you
at an earlier day but I suppose and know that like myself
your moments are so engrossed that you have barely time to
attend to the more pressing duties which claim your attention

When I left Mobile last summer I had firmly intended to
call upon you and have a long conference with you in several
subjects of gr considerable importance to the cause of our
religion but being detained at N arlington on my way
I was obliged to omit my intended stay at Philadelphia
whilst journeying northward. Contemplating to return to
your city for a few days during my stay at the
north. Engagements of various character so far
interfered with my views as to render it impracticable
and nt I had so timed myself on my return trip
home reference to the Holidays. that I could not
delay a moment in Philadelphia. I regret exceedingly
that I did not have the pleasure of meeting you

but in the event of my again traveling northward in the
ensuing summer I shall certainly make arrangements to be
with you for a day or two under any circumstances or
& In relation to your subscribers in this place please
mention the amounts due by each for I have no copy of
the letter in which I forwarded the remittance and do not
remember how the amounts were paid. Please specify the
sum due by each to the end of the third volume.

I will see Goldsmith and he will I feel satisfied
continue his subscription. he was probably absent from
the city when his number was left remaining in the
Post office.

We afford one peculiar qualification to announce
to you the success which has attended our efforts in this
city in the establishment of a congregation and place
of worship. On Friday evening 27th Kislev,
corresponding with 26 Dec. we opened for the first time
the new place of building which we have? had latterly? been
preparing for the our use. It was originally used by
the Episcopalians from whom it passed into the
hands of the Unitarians and upon the disorganization
of that society in our city the Universalists obtained leased
it and not used by them during the preceding year.
That Sect having obtained purchased another building
the congregation concluded to leave this one and
have taken it for a term of years. We have filled
fitted it up, in a style of simplicity and neatness which

will accord it a place amongst the most costly of our synagogues
in this country. The design we have had in view was
beauty and taste without any ostentatious or gaudy display
of architecture. The work therefore is plain yet so
exceedingly neat and all the appointments being so
complete even to the covering of the entire floor that the
coup d'oeuil strikes every beholder with admiration and
satisfaction. The opening services were under the direction
of W. Da Silva formely of New York who has been appointed
as h reader to the congregation. In the absence of a choir
and from the fact that many and in fact a majority of
our members are unacquainted with the Portuguese
mode of reading, the services ceremonies were
very simple and included ? little more
than the ordinary service of for the Eve of the
Sabbath with the addition of a discourse delivered by
Col. D. Solomon. It will suffice perhaps to express to you
the universal satisfaction which with which his remarks were
received. There has been a general feeling of
favour and interest manifested in our undertaking by all
our coreligionists in the city and I trust I will not
be considerd as neglecting others if I particularly name
the zeal with which the President of the Congregation
(Mail I Jones Eq) has conducted the enterprise until its
happy consummation. We are now fairly embarked under
the most auspicious circumstance and feel every confidence in progressing rapidly and satisfactorily.”

Relative to the matter of the Jewish Publication Society and also
in regard to your edition of the Pentateuch I will lay them
before the Board of ? and the congregation and hope
that we shall be able to do something for you. one dem The
demands which we have lately made upon the liberality of
our friends in the completion of our undertaking here makes
me somewhat fearful that th all the success I could wish
for may not perhaps attend my presentation of the projects.

Please let me know whether you have any edit separate
numbers of the “Daily Prayer Book” and what would be
the price for 10 or 15 of them.

In regard to my next number of “Short Sermons” I
have not commenced it because I did not know
whether you might would deem them worthy of publication
and was awaiting your reply. Keep a place for me
however in your paper until the 20th of the month
when I will endeavour to have another number in
your hands so that it can be published in February? number.

It would meet the views of your friends here
and might perpa perhaps serve some what the course of
our religion by publishing that portion of their letter
which I have marked relative to the opening of
our new place of worship.

You may expect to hear from me again in
something less than ten days.
but I send this in haste
